awd_titl_txt: A Stronger Atom-Light Interface and Enhanced Spin Squeezing Through Quantum Control
awd_abstract_narration:
This project has as its main objective to develop new methods that strengthen the quantum interface between atoms and light, and to use this as a tool for enhanced control of the quantum mechanical spin associated with a collection of atoms.  The central idea is that by preparing certain non-trivial states of the internal atomic spins, one can greatly increase the sensitivity of a laser probe to quantum uncertainty in the collective spin.  In that situation, using the laser probe to perform an accurate measurement of the spin will reduce, or squeeze, quantum noise on the spin below currently achievable levels.  Further control of the internal spins can convert such spin squeezing into forms that improve the performance of atomic clocks, magnetometers, or matter-wave based inertial sensors.

The research contributes to the knowledge basis of quantum metrology and quantum information science.  Short-term applications include future generations of quantum-limited clocks and sensors, while long-term applications are possible in quantum memories and other hardware required for the nodes in quantum communication networks.  Graduate students are involved in all aspects of the project, including training, research, and the dissemination of results.  The project is a cornerstone of the NSF-supported Center for Quantum Information and Control (CQuIC), co-located at the University of Arizona and the University of New Mexico.  As such, it contributes to the training of a wider group of future scientists and engineers in the highly interdisciplinary field of quantum information science.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. The past two decades has seen a shift in our perspective on quantum mechanics, from a theory that mainly describes naturally occurring phenomena, to a theory that governs our ability to design and use complex physical systems for technological purposes. With that shift has come new opportunities that go beyond classical physics, and this has brought profound changes to the way we think of devices ranging from computers to precision sensors. This project has contributed to our general quantum technology toolbox mainly through the development of a high-performance atom-light quantum interface. The interface was used as a quantum bus to connect distant members of a cold atom cloud, with the goal of creating quantum many body states with reduced quantum uncertainty in the collective spin. Such spin squeezed states have the potential to improve the accuracy of quantum limited magnetometers, inertial sensors, and atomic clocks.  Specific accomplishments of the project include

  • Use of the atom-light interface to probe the collective spin associated with a collection of ~106 laser cooled cesium atoms. This was done by entangling the polarization of the light with a component of the collective spin, such that a measurement of the former corresponded to a non-destructive quantum limited measurement of the latter. A careful study was done to quantify fundamental  quantum uncertainty in the spin measurement and separate it from technical noise sources.
  • Demonstration of conditional spin squeezing in the laboratory. This was observed as a reduction in the relative uncertainty between two successive spin measurements, to a level ~3dB below the quantum uncertainty of either measurement on its own. Whereas previous demonstrations relied on simple 2-level atoms, this experiment was the first to achieve squeezing with complex multilevel atoms having large internal spins.
  • A demonstration that internal-state control of complex multi-level atoms can improve the entangling power of an atom-light quantum interface and the spin squeezing it can produce. This novel approach applies the standard quantum measurement to atoms whose internal states are prepared as a superposition of spins pointing in opposite directions (sometimes referred to as a “Schrödinger cat” state).  As much as 8dB of conditional squeezing was observed, a roughly 5dB improvement over the standard approach.
  • These accomplishments required a number of advances in theoretical and experimental quantum optics and atomic physics.  Notable examples include a complete theory of diffraction in 3-dimensional atom-light interfaces and its use to maximize atom-light coupling in the laboratory, the use of two-color light fields to eliminate spin dependent light shifts that otherwise destroy squeezing in complex multilevel atoms, and the development of a suite of techniques for extremely accurate control of applied and ambient magnetic fields.

Broad impact.  The project has contributed to the knowledge base of atomic, molecular and optical physics and of quantum information science.  It has contributed to the recruitment and training of future scientists by providing dissertation topics and funding for 3 full time students at the University of Arizona, one of whom graduated with the PhD in 2015 and is now a staff research scientist at a local R&D company. The PI’s research group is a cornerstone of the Center for Quantum Information and Control, and partners in regular activities through which the project has impacted a broader community of students, postdocs, faculty and staff at the University of New Mexico, Sandia and Los Alamos National Labs, and other CQuIC partner institutions.
